Doctors strike.description: KOLKATA: Junior doctors in Bengal finally called off their week-long strike and promised to resume duty on Tuesday morning, ending a stir that crippled out patient departments (OPDs) and severely hit emergency services at hospitals across the state. At a meeting held at state secretariat Nabanna on Monday evening, West Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee told a team of 31 junior doctors, " Lakkhi chhele, ebar tomra strike tule nao (Please withdraw your strike like good boys)", which they agreed to. The "cordial" negotiations between the CM and doctors were broadcast live for about 100 minutes by two regional channels. The doctors, who had adopted a strident posture against the administration for the initial police inaction against the kin of a bereaved patient at NRS Hospital last Monday (incident that triggered the stir) relented in the face of genuine-sounding assurances from the CM. The state administration medical fraternity face-off escalated after Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee issued a stern warning of action against the strike during her visit to SSKM Hospital last Thursday. What could have also played on their minds was the rising public opinion against the continuing strike, especially after the CM's appeal for talks last weekend. The striking doctors returned to the NRS campus on Monday and, after another general-body meeting, made a statement: "We hereby announce the withdrawal of the strike by junior doctors." Several issues were discussed at the meeting. They ranged from security measures - collapsible gates for emergency wards, regulated entry for patients' kin and enhanced police presence on medical campuses with nodal officers responsible for law and order - to the CM's suggestion for third-party PR professionals, who could act as grief counsellors and handle communication between "overworked doctors" and "aggrieved patients' kin" and grievance cells for patients. "We are delighted with the cordial manner in which the meeting was held, the CM's caring touch and concrete suggestions and assurances to the issues raised by us," one of the junior doctors said. "They (doctors) have genuine demands. We have listened to them and taken decisions to resolve them. This must be a continuous process. We have to see to it that such untoward incidents are averted and action is taken if something happens," Mamata said. The CM's "gentleness", however, came with the message that she could not be bullied. Urged by the junior doctors to visit the doctor who was injured in the NRS attack, and come to the NRS campus, she said, "Leave certain things to us...Give me your word that you will resume duty." St Thomas Mount metro station toilets lo.description: CHENNAI: Commuters who walked in to St Thomas Mount metro station on Monday noon were shocked to find the toilets closed and barricaded due to shortage of water. A board hung outside the toilet read ‘ toilet’s closed- due to non-availability of water. Sorry for the inconvenience caused- CMRL St Thomas Mount.’ Vignesh, who works at a media outlet, wanted to use the restroom before boarding train to his office in Teynampet. “There were barricades in front of the toilet, and a board was hung next to it with a message that the toilet is closed due to non-availability of water,” he said. A photograph of the notice board that Vignesh captured was shared on social media later in the day. Washrooms at other stations were open. When asked, CMRL denied this saying it was a baseless rumour and that there was no water shortage. “Adequate measures have been taken for the benefit of metro passengers. There is no water shortage at the metro stations and all restrooms are being used by passengers,” said a statement from CMRL. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Vikiravandi constituency in Tamil Nadu d.description: CHENNAI: The Tamil Nadu assembly secretariat on Monday announced that Vikiravandi constituency is vacant after the death of sitting MLA K Rathamani last week. With this, there are two vacant constituencies in Tamil Nadu. Nanguneri MLA H Vasanthkumar resigned last month after being elected from Kanyakumari Lok Sabha constituency, and the seat was declared vacant. "The assembly secretariat will soon inform the election department about the vacancy in Vikiravandi which will in turn inform the Election Commission," said a senior official. The total strength of the assembly now is 232 against its full strength of 234. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Western, southwestern parts to be hotter.description: CHENNAI: Have you wondered why Mogappair is hotter than Mylapore? Or the night temperature suddenly dips when you near Gandhi Mandapam from Little Mount? Well, the team at Centre for Climate Change and Adaptation Research, Anna University, which studied the thermal comfort level in Chennai has an answer. Researchers said western and southwestern parts of the city show higher discomfort and the most obvious reason for this is rapid urbanisation without providing for any green cover. With very few trees, these concrete jungles have become heat islands. While studying variations of temperature indicative of urban heat islands, the team noticed maximum intensity of temperature in central and north Chennai. These are distinguished commercial centres and also densely populated residential areas. Extended areas such as Avadi, Poonamalee in the west and Tambaram, Medavakkam in the southwest record higher temperatures due to unplanned urbanisation, researchers said citing that concrete tends to retain the sun’s heat. The result of this will be extended summers and excessive rainfall in future climate scenarios, the researchers said. “Heat island is a product of urban climate. Cities in tropical countries suffer extensively due to the urban heat island effect and urban climate studies are necessary to improve the comfort level and city planning,” said Anushiya, a member of the research team. Nerkundram: Water tanker kills woman, in.description: CHENNAI: A water tanker smashed into four people at Nerkundram on Monday, killing a woman. The accident took place at 4.30am. The deceased was identified as Kaliammal, 44, of Perumal Koil Street in Nerkundram. The injured were Vijaykumar, 59, her husband, Tamil Selvan, 31, of Gummidipoondi and Bakiyaraj, 33, of Nerkundram. Vijayakumar and his wife were waiting for an auto. The tanker which was going to Maduravoyal rammed two parked motorbikes and then plouged into the group at the bus stop. Kaliammal was dragged for about 30m, after which the vehicle came to a halt. A witness said there was no time to run for safety as the driver could not bring the vehicle under control. He managed to escape from the scene but was later arrested and identified as Vijaya Balan of Myiladuthurai. Investigations revealed he had dozed off at the wheels which led to the accident. Police registered a case of causing death due to negligence, rash and negligent driving. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Yogi Adityanath.description: VARANASI: Uttar Pradesh chief minister Yogi Adityanath slammed Congress president Rahul Gandhi for suddenly showing concern for the poor and asked why he didn’t ensure a minimum income scheme for them during Congress-led UPA regime when his mother Sonia Gandhi acted as ‘super prime minister’ and had a say in everything. Targeting Congress announcement of minimum income scheme for poor on coming to power, Yogi said, “Congress led UPA was in power in Centre from 2004 to 2014. Everybody knows how Rahul and his mother (Sonia Gandhi) were influential in UPA regime. However, in UPA’s 10-year regime Congress never showed the kind of sympathy for poor, unemployed, farmers and women of country like it is showing now for Pakistan.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest Elections News.

Met forecasts two-day heatwave in Chenna.description: CHENNAI: People of Tamil Nadu may not get any respite from the sweltering heat at least for the next two days as the meteorological department has forecast heatwave conditions for Chennai, Kancheepuram and Tiruvallur districts. The southern and northern suburbs are likely to be hotter than the core areas of the city. The warning, issued till June 18, said that isolated areas in Tiruvallur, Vellore and Tiruvannamalai districts, and areas along the east coast of the city till Puducherry could come under the grip of the heatwave, with temperature soaring above 40C. The maximum temperature in the city will be above 40C for the next two days. A forecast for the city said: “The sky condition is likely to be partly cloudy. maximum and minimum temperatures are likely to be around 41 degree C and 31 degree C respectively.” Met department has also issued a warning to the people not to expose themselves to direct sunlight between 11am and 4pm to avoid sunstroke. On Sunday, the city recorded 40.2degree C and Meenambakkam recorded 42degree Celcius. The highest temperature recorded last year for June was 39.8 on June 6 and 15th. In 2017, the maximum temperature has crossed 40degree C in June. However, Erode, Coimbatore, Nilgiris, Salem, Theni, Dindigul, Kanyakumari, Shivaganga and Pudukottai districts will experience light to moderate rain. AIADMK not to oppose key bills in Parlia.description: CHENNAI: With the first session of the 17th Lok Sabha beginning Monday, the ruling AIADMK has decided not to oppose the contentious dam safety and motor vehicles bills nor confront the NDA government. While its lone MP in the LS and 13 members in RS will raise concerns of the state and move amendments, it will not stand in the way of passage of crucial bills in both Houses, sources said. The controversial clauses of the bills were taken up by chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami in his meeting with Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Saturday, seeking his intervention. “There will not be any confrontation with the Centre nor any opposition to the bills. We will continue to raise the concerns of the state as they (Centre) are concerned about the entire nation. The amendments will be moved by the MPs as per instructions from the high command,” said a senior AIADMK leader. While the dam safety bill was introduced in LS in December last year, the motor vehicles amendments bill was passed in April and both lapsed with the dissolution of the 16th Lok Sabha. The Tamil Nadu assembly had passed an unanimous resolution in June last year not to enact a law on dam safety until the states were consulted and consensus was evolved. The main concern of the state was that the bill envisages a national dam safety authority that would act as state dam safety organization for a dam located in one state and owned by another. It would only mean that the state owning the dam would have no rights over the safety and maintenance of the dam located in another state. Mullaperiyar, Parambikulam, Thunakadavu and Peruvaripallam dams are owned, operated and maintained by Tamil Nadu by inter-state agreements, but located in Kerala. With 37 MPs, the AIADMK, as the third largest party in Parliament, had raised strong objections when the bills were introduced last year. “This time, the AIADMK will only object to eroding the rights of Tamil Nadu, which is a violation of the federal principles, and seek amendments to the clauses,” said a senior minister. While the Centre aims at reforming the transport sector with the proposed amendments to Motor Vehicles Act, 1988, the Tamil Nadu government demands that the Centre modifies five clauses, which even overruns the nationalisation policy of the state. A clause eliminates the monopoly of the states to carry on transport business and feared to weaken or even terminate the service of state transport undertakings. Shiv Sena List 2019.description: MUMBAI: Shiv Sena has come up with it's first list of 21 candidates, out of 23 to contest in Lok Sabha polls in Maharashtra. Except Osmanabad, 17 sitting Sena MP's are part of the list, includes Mumbai, Thane, Kalyan, Raigad. Following complaints received by local functionaries from Osmanabad, the party has denied ticket to sitting MP Ravindra Gaikwad. Gaikwad, who had allegedly hit an Air India staffer with his slipper because he was refused a business class seat in March 2017. Maharashtra: Track here Lok Sabha elections' full coverageSena has kept two seats, Palghar and Satara, on hold, likely to announce on Sunday. Late Chintaman Wanga, former BJP MP's son Shrinivas likely to contest from Palghar on Sena ticket whereas former NCP legislator Narendra Patil may might contest as Sena candidate from Satara. Patil met Shiv Sena president Uddhav Thackeray on Friday at Matoshree. Other candidates are: South Mumbai: Arvind Sawant; South Central Mumbai: Rahul Shewale; Mumbai North West: Gajanan Kirtikar; Kalyan: Shrikant Shinde; Raigad: union minister Anant Gite; Osmanabad: Omraje Nimbalkar, Ratnagiri-Sindhudurg: Vinayak Raut; Kolhapur-Sanjay Mandlik; Hatkanangle: Dhairyasheel Mane; Nashik: Hemant Godse; Shirdi: Sadashiv Lokhande; Shirur: Shivajirao Adhalrao Patil; Aurangabad: Chandrakant Khaire; Yavatmal Washim: Bhawana Gawli; Buldana: Prataprao Jadhav; Ramtek: Kripal Tumane; Amrawati-Anandrao Adsul, Parbhani: Sanjay Jadhav; Maval: Shrirang Barne; Hingoli: Hemant Patil. Clinic to be set up in Guindy Children's.description: CHENNAI: Soon injured and sick wildlife from Children’s Park won’t have to be transported to Vandalur zoo for treatment, as forest officials are planning to set up a clinic there. Officials have identified at least half a dozen places in Children’s Park and forest staff quarters area, located within the Guindy National Park. The clinic will be set up in one of these six places. The department is involved in rescuing free roaming spotted deer which are found in about a dozen residential localities in the city. When these free roaming animals are rescued, they get injured at times. So they need medical attention immediately, like their counterparts in captivity in the park. A senior official from the animal husbandry department visited the Children’s Park and also the quarters area recently. Officials wanted to convert a small building which was earlier used by biologists and researchers. Now that place is lying vacant. However, only after animal husbandry authorities point out the suitable space, the veterinary clinic will be set up there. The department has already sent proposals to provide financial assistance to set up and run the clinic, added an officer. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Let\u2019s learn from past floods to dea.description: Chennai suffers from a scarcity of ideas, not rain or water. A classic example is the 2015 floods and the water paucity a year-and-a-half later. Flood water from Adyar river entered homes, caused extensive damage, and a large quantum of it drained into the sea under the watchful eyes of the city planners. Chennai has been banking on three water reservoirs for the past 100 years, with the government not setting up a new reservoir that could at least store Krishna water from Andhra Pradesh or collect rainwater in the city suburbs. In the past 30 years no proper step has been taken to increase the city’s water capacity despite its growing population. At one point of time, the DMK government considered establishing two reservoirs to store Krishna water but dropped the plan. Instead, Krishna water was taken to the existing Poondi reservoir. The AIADMK government too failed to create an additional reservoir though Rs500 crore was sanctioned in 2012. Had these plans been implemented, the city probably would not have suffered massive damage due to the floods in 2015, and saved part of the water too. In 2017, the Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) in the Performance Audit of Flood Management and Response in Chennai and its Suburban Area highlighted several failures on the part of the Tamil Nadu government which led to the "manmade disaster". The CAG report noted, "Considering the catastrophic floods in 1976, TN constituted a nucleus cell to suggest flood mitigation measures." Creation of two reservoirs in the upstream of Chembarambakkam tank on Adyar river to capture 1.57 thousand million cubic feet (tmcft) of water was recommended in 1980. "We noticed that after a delay of seven years, water resources department (WRD) in 1987 proposed a reservoir at Thiruneermalai, by which time the site had become populated and requisite land was not available. Thus, the WRD failed to construct the reservoir which could have accommodated the surplus water in Adyar river in 2015. Instead of creating new reservoirs upstream Chembarambakkam tank, TN envisaged three tanks across the Kosasthalayar river to augment storage by 4.2tmcft." These three projects proved to be disappointments, the report said, pointing out that against an outlay of Rs500.36 crore to increase the storage capacity by 1.83tmcft, an expenditure of Rs289.63 crore was incurred until the end of March 2016 to achieve an increase of only 0.17tmcft. The state has now announced that a new reservoir would be built, combining the Orathur, Arambakkam tanks and Orathur check dam in Sriperumbudur taluk, with a capacity of 1.3tmcft at a cost of Rs60 crore by 2021, even while the proposed new reservoir at Thervaikandigai (Rs330 crore) is under construction. The Thervaikandigai proposal has suffered due to faulty land acquisition resulting in enormous delay, according to the CAG report. In 2011-12, TN also envisaged construction of a reservoir at Thirukandalam in Tiruvallur district across Kosasthalayar river to store 1tmcft of water downstream of Poondi reservoir and Thamaraipakkam Anicut. As the proposal required acquisition of private land across 1,376.52 hectare, on government orders, WRD downsized the project to construct a check dam to store 0.16tmcft. The structure was designed to withstand a maximum flood discharge of 65,000 cusec, but the WRD failed to take into account the discharge of 92,260 cusec at Poondi reservoir in 1966. The work was completed in September 2014 at a cost of Rs28.65 crore. During the floods in 2015, the retaining wall of the check dam breached due to inflow of 79,564 cusec. The CAG report observed that the imprudent decision of TN to reduce the storage capacity to avoid land acquisition resulted in failure to harness excess water. "Incorrect adoption of flood discharge capacity for construction of the check dam resulted in its breach during 2015 floods thereby causing inundation of nearby areas," the report stated. Further, TN did not consider construction of check dams at Varadharajapuram and Anakaputhur villages to harness surplus floodwater of Adyar river despite it being recommended by the expert committee on northeast monsoon. On the contrary, it allowed the Airports Authority of India to demolish a check dam across the Adyar. Construction of the suggested check dams, could, to an extent, have reduced the flow of flood water. Encroachment of tanks, lakes and river beds also played a major role in causing the massive floods in Chennai and the present scarcity. Large-scale illegal constructions and lack of implementation of rainwater harvesting systems contributed to the present crisis. Thousands of waterbodies in Greater Chennai region are crying for attention, which are cost-effective water sources for the parched city. The solution lies within. The question is will there be an end to the dearth of ideas. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

15 women\u2019s hostels downed shutters.description: CHENNAI: The water crisis has hit those running hostels in the city. Fifteen working women’s hostels and one lodge have shut down in the past one month as they did not have water. “Hostels could not sustain as the private water tankers were unable to provide water. Moving from the regular practice of paying the tankers after delivery, we offered them advances, still the tankers were unable to supply forcing the hostels to shut down,” said Tamil Nadu Hostel Owners Welfare Association founder president Shobana Madhavan. After private tankers, distribution of bubble top cans too has become an issue. According Madhavan, can suppliers have reduced the number of cans for private women’s hostels. “It is becoming difficult to sustain in the business due and more hostels may close if the situation continues,” she said. There are around 2,000 working women’s hostels in Chennai and its suburbs. Working women from other districts and states depend on these facilities. Lodges at Chepauk and Triplicane are also on the verge of closure due to water scarcity. Hasan Ali, president of Triplicane Taluk Mansion Owners Association, said one lodge at Chepauk was closed last month. “The private water tankers are charging too much. A 12,000-litre that would cost Rs 1,200 shot up to Rs 4,000,” he said. Under such circumstances, the lodge owners, who provide budget accommodations and hence run on a tight budget, have little option but to shut shop. Chepauk and Triplicane are the hub of such lodges, called mansions locally. There are 500 such mansions, each of them with 10 to 50 rooms. On an average, such lodges have an occupancy rate of 60%. But Ali said ever since the borewells have gone dry, the situation has become grim. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Corpn earns Rs 2.13 lakh from plastic fi.description: CHENNAI: Six months after putting a ban on plastic in place, the corporation on Monday, for the first time, began penalizing violators. It raided 1,831 shops in 153 locations and collected Rs 2.13 lakh fine. It also served 57 notices to shop owners and seized 832kg of plastic. At Koyambedu market, two shops and one godown were locked and each fined Rs 25,000. “We locked the godown,” said Selvanayagam, an assistant engineer. In Perungudi zone, 77 shops were fined Rs 39,100 and 21kg of plastic seized — the highest. In Madhavaram, 68 shops were fined Rs 29,100 and 15kg of plastic seized. In Kodambakkam, 234 shops were fined Rs 27,000 and 24kg of plastic seized. As per a February government order, Rs 2 lakh is the fine for manufacture of banned plastic items, first time. For trading, retailing, selling and distributing, it is Rs 50,000, while it is Rs 25,000 for commercial users. Domestic users can be fined Rs 500 for first time offence and Rs 1,000 for subsequent violations. A corporation health official said they were asked to initially focus on big commercial establishments. “First, we want to cut down the supply. So, we will only concentrate on those storing them. After that retail shops will be penalised. We have formed teams and will inspect every day. We are issuing receipts for the penalties imposed,” he said. Corporation deputy commissioner (health) P Madhusudhan Reddy hoped the move would act as a deterrent. “We will hold workshops to create awareness and promote alternative products,” he said. Since January 1, about 250 metric tonnes of plastic items were seized and sent to private pyrolysis plants. Residents say this may not change much on the ground. Social activist V Umanath of Mogappair said the government missed an opportunity. “Imposing fines won’t help as all establishments will form a syndicate and pay bribes. Initially, there were a lot of people including myself who ordered alternative products. After a month, it faded away.” Resident Sathish Ramasamy said, “Unless the government comes up with proper alternatives for plastic, the ban can never be implemented properly.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Tamil Nadu CM seeks public support for p.description: CHENNAI: Tamil Nadu chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami on Monday requested the public to extend support to the plastic ban being enforced by the government from January 1 onwards. He held a review meeting at the secretariat with the ministers and heads of various departments on the action taken against violations. “The general public should make use of alternative products to plastic and help the state government in its efforts to preserve the environment,” an official release quoting the chief minister said. The meeting discussed the penalty imposed on establishments and cancelling their licences for the violations. The departments were directed to encourage the public to use alternative products and take action against violators. The state has fixed the penalty for the first-time offence of storage, supply, transport, sale and distribution of use and throwaway plastics at Rs 25,000. For the second-time offence, the penalty will be Rs 50,000 while it will be Rs 1 lakh for the third-time offence. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Residents sing hosanna to \u2018Chennai.description: CHENNAI: To mark their gratitude, people of Pallavaram municipality have got together to give the man who cleaned their sewers for 37 years a grand farewell when he retires at the end of the month. They’ve even penned a poem in his honour. G Yesu, 60, is elated that people recognize his dedication to duty. “Like me, I want everyone to keep our city clean,” he told TOI at his home in a slum in Krishna Nagar in Chromepet. “I vividly remember the first time I saw him during cyclone Vardah. The drains were blocked by fallen trees and the streets were a mess as conservancy workers stayed away. He was the only worker to be seen every day in our area helping us clean the roads and drains,” said D Devaraj, treasurer, Chromepet New Colony Resident Welfare Association. V Santhanam, who’s penned a poem on Yesu, said, “Whenever we cross a drain or a garbage bin, we cover our noses. But this man enters cesspools and cleans them for us. He is so righteous that he has never sought an extra paisa. In fact, when we offer him money, he refuses it.” R Ramadas, another resident of the municipality, said that if every residents’ association recognized such people’s work, it would motivate not just the workers but also people to become socially conscious. Yesu says he came to the city from Andhra Pradesh in the 1970s and wanted to become a peon in an office. But since he had only passed Class V, he ended up with a job as a conservancy worker clearing drains. But he has no regrets. “My children (he has three) often told me to do some other job. But it is because of this job that I could educate them,” he says. So what after June 30? Yesu says he will find some work as he cannot sit idle. Residents say they will miss him. PM Modi.description: JEYPORE: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Friday said his government had taken measures to set up a 'chowkidar' in space and asked people to vote for a government that can take concrete decisions and not just raise slogans. Launching his campaign in eastern India with a rally in Jeypore area of Odisha's Koraput district, the prime minister said the NDA government wouldn't have been able to do any development work in the country without the support of the people. He sought blessings from his supporters for the 2019 Lok Sabha elections and asserted that the NDA government has left no stone unturned to bring about development in the state. Land, air or space, we had courage to do surgical strikes: PM Modi"The NDA government has been working hard to develop road and rail infrastructure in the state. There is no dearth of funds when it comes to development work in the country. "In the last five years, the government has been able to build homes for eight lakh families, light up 3,000 houses and provide gas connections to 40 lakh homes," Modi stated. Referring to Mission Shakti, when India demonstrated anti-satellite (ASAT) missile capability by shooting down a live satellite, he said the government has taken measures to set up a 'chowkidar' (watchman) in space. He came down heavily on opposition parties who he said "belittled" the space achievement. "Those that are criticising the anti-satellite technology will be given a befitting reply in the elections," he claimed, urging people to vote for a government that can take concrete decisions, not the one that only raises slogans. BJP List 2019 Maharashtra.description: AURANGABAD/KOLHAPUR: Sitting MPs Sunil Gaikwad (Latur) and Dilip Gandhi (Ahmednagar) were denied tickets for the forthcoming Lok Sabha elections in the BJP’s first national list of candidates announced on Thursday. The list included 16 names from Maharashtra. While speculations were rife that the party would not retain Gaikwad owing to his differences with some senior BJP leaders, what came as a surprise was the ticket going to Sudhakar Shrungare, a member of the Latur zilla parishad. However, Shrungare, who is in the construction business, was the popular choice of local BJP workers. Gaikwad had won the 2014 election by a majority of over 2.5 lakh votes. Considered to be close to Union minister Nitin Gadkari, he was reportedly at loggerheads with Latur district guardian minister Sambhaji Patil-Nilangekar. The nomination of Sujay Vikhe Patil, son of senior Congress leader Radhakrishna Vikhe Patil, from Ahmednagar instead of Gandhi was a foregone conclusion ever since he joined the party last week. Sujay, a neurosurgeon by profession, will be making his entry into politics with this nomination. His late grandfather, Balasaheb Vikhe Patil, was long associated with the Congress. | Full coverage of Lok Sabha elections in MaharashtraAmong other prominent leaders from Maharashtra in the first list of candidates are Union minister Nitin Gadkari from his hometown Nagpur, state BJP chief Raosaheb Danve from Jalna, Union MoS Hansraj Ahir from Chandrapur and Union MoS for defence Subash Bhamre from Dhule. Late BJP MP Gopinath Munde’s daughter, Pritam, who was elected to Parliament with a record majority after her father’s death, has been renominated from Beed. Sitting MP from Sangli Sanjay Patil has also been renominated, putting an end to speculation over any change in constituency. Patil’s candidature was opposed by a section of BJP leaders in Sangli. However, chief minister Devendra Fadnavis is understood to have called a meeting of local party leaders and resolved the differences. The party has also given tickets to Heena Gavit from Nandurbar, Raksha Khadse from Raver, Poonam Mahajan from Mumbai North Central, Kapil Patil from Bhiwandi, Sanjay Dhotre from Akola, Ramdas Tadas from Wardha, Ashok Nete from Gadchiroli and Gopal Shetty from Mumbai North. Chennai IT companies are not facing wate.description: CHENNAI: Tamil Nadu rural and municipal administration minister S P Velumani on Monday denied reports that IT companies in Chennai are facing water storage. “None of the IT companies in the city are facing water shortage. Hotels have sufficient water, schools are not facing any shortage and hostels are not closing down,” the minister said at a press meet here. “Based on media reports, we spoke to the IT firms and we did not find any water shortage. They are dependent on private water tankers. If they require supply, we can support them,” he said. The minister said domestic water supply had been increased from 450 MLD in 2017 to 525 MLD now. This supply would be maintained till November. Defying reports about water shortage, Velumani said, “There is no shortage of drinking water. Sufficient supply is reaching the residents as we have augmented several sources such as stone quarries, additional lake supply from Retteri and Ayanambakkam. We are also drawing water from aquifers near Neyveli Lignite Corporation. In future, if required, we will get water from other districts. But presently, we are able to manage the supply,” he said. He said, “There is a rainfall deficit. But Chennai Metrowater and the state government were managing well and are supplying enough water to residents.” He said that the government was desilting and rejuvenating more than 610 water bodies in Chennai which will increase the storage capacity of water by 1 TMC. “All the negative stories and publicity is politically motivated and are not true. It is to ensure that companies don’t come to Chennai,” said Velumani. The minister said that he had held a review with officials from all corporations, municipalities and town panchayats. “Special teams will be constituted, and grievances will be redressed immediately. Redressal number 044-45674567 will work 24x7. Apartments will be asked to use recycled water and ward level water supply will be monitored,” he said. Woman dies in stampede at PDS shop.description: TIRUVANNAMALAI: A 63-year-old woman died in a stampede at a public distribution system (PDS) outlet in Inamkariyandhal village in Tiruvannamalai district on Monday. The woman, identified as Dhanabakiyam, was waiting to buy her monthly provisions, when she was pushed to the ground. Police said the stampede occurred when the crowd of ration card holders, mostly women, surged forward. Dhanabakiyam, who was caught in the stampede, was found lying unconscious. As confusion prevailed, a few villagers managed to pull Dhanabakiyam, trapped under the crowd of women, out and carry her to a nearby house. They tried to revive her by sprinkling water on her face. They then took her to the Government Tiruvannamalai Medical College and Hospital where she was declared dead. The Tiruvannamalai taluk police registered a case. The incident occurred around 9 am when the outlet salesman R Krishnan asked the women to stand in a queue to receive the supplies and went inside to prepare the tokens. Some of the women, who tried to move forward, broke the line, falling on Dhanabakiyam. When contacted, Tiruvannamalai district collector K S Kandasamy said, “According to officials, there is very little possibility of the woman having died in a stampede. A team of civil supplies officials is, however, conducting a probe,” the collector told TOI. He denied villagers’ allegation that the shop was opened only twice a month. Tiruvannamalai taluk supply officer K Sumathi, heading the probe, also denied that the PDS outlet was opened only twice a month. She said 200 ration card holders had queued up before the shop when the woman was found unconscious. “But, the salesman Krishnan was not aware of how the woman died until an ambulance reached the spot to take her to the hospital. He was busy preparing the tokens to be distributed,” she said. “Preliminary enquiries revealed that the woman had skipped her breakfast. She fell unconscious while standing in the queue,” the officer said. Villagers, however, maintained that the utlet was opened to them only twice a month due to gross shortage of supplies. Former village councilor P Karunanidhi said though the outlet catered to more than 900 ration card holders from three villages in the neighbourhood, including Inamkariyandhal, S Mottur and Varattakuttai, due to shortage of supplies of the essential commodities, it was opened only twice a month. Vijayalakshmi, a villager, added it was due to the laxity of the salesman Krishnan, that the ration shop was opened just twice a month. “Officials should take steps to open the outlet every day, or they should open more PDS outlets in each village to avert such tragedies,” she said. Chennai airport customs officials seize.description: CHENNAI: Customs officials at Chennai international airport on Monday seized 1.1kg of gold hidden in a Bluetooth speaker and arrested a passenger who smuggled it from a foreign country. Customs officials said they had intercepted Sadik Shaik, 22, of Chittoor in Andhra Pradesh, who arrived here from Riyadh via Bahrain in a Gulf Air flight. The passenger was questioned. As he was evasive in his replies, his baggage was taken up for examination. During the examination of his checked-in baggage, one Bluetooth speaker was found. On examination, ten gold bars with foreign markings and one gold cut bar -- totally weighing 1.1kg and worth at Rs 38 lakh -- were found concealed ingeniously inside the speaker. 331 schools in Chennai lose recognition.description: CHENNAI: The Chennai district collectorate on Monday released the list of schools functioning without obtaining government's recognition. Collector A Shanmuga Sudaram has requested parents not to admit their children in any of the 331 unrecognised schools. They include Kidzee Play School at Ashok Nagar, Sri Sri Ravi Shankar Vidya Mandir at West Mambalam and American Kidz International Montessori Education at Velachery. No school is allowed to operate without obtaining recognition from the respective state governments. It should be renewed every three years, according to the Right of Children for Free and Compulsory Education (RTE) Act, 2009. Recently, students from a private school in Chennai, claiming to have CBSE affiliation, were unable to take up their annual board exams. Authorities came to know they didn't obtain any recognition from the government. To avoid this, the state school education department in April formed district-level committees to inspect schools and update recognition process. During the said process, the committee -- based in Chennai -- found out that the said 313 schools didn't meet the eligibility criteria and it was better to shut them before the start of academic year so that students and parents didn’t suffer mid-way. Earlier, a list of 25 unrecognised schools in Tiruvallur district was released. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Chennai: Burglars strike at police quart.description: CHENNAI:Even the police quarters aren’t off limits for burglars in the city. A traffic special sub-inspector and his family returning home after a week away found the lock of their home in the police quarters at Madhavaram broke and 13 sovereigns of gold jewellery and Rs2000 in cash missing from their almirah on Sunday morning. This is the second burglary in a police quarters in the city in a week. On Thursday night, burglars sneaked into the house of a woman constable at Kondithope police quarters and escaped with valuables. The SSI, Kothandaraman, 51, who is attached to Sembium traffic enforcement and lived on the first floor of A block, had gone to Thiruchendur on June 13. The burglary came to light only when the family returned home. They had kept the key on top of the almirah, which came in handy for the burglars. Based on the complaint from the SSI, Madhavaram police went to the scene and collected fingerprints. Police suspect the hand of someone inside the quarters as outsiders cannot sneak in easily. Police have collected the CCTV from Madhavaram police station, which is located right opposite the quarters. There are 7 blocks in the quarters with 12 apartments in each block. Pvt colleges exploit delay in Anna Univ.description: CHENNAI: Deemed universities and private engineering colleges are capitalising on the delay in conducting Anna University counselling. While most private establishments are on the verge of completing admissions, the government committee formed to conduct Tamil Nadu Engineering Admissions (TNEA) 2019 has postponed counselling. The rank list, which was to be released on Monday, will be released today, i.e. June 20 and counselling for special category candidates — people with disabilities and eminent sports persons — will begin on June 25, according to an official release. READ ALSO: TNEA 2019 Rank List to be out shortly @ tneaonline.in“Every day of delay is advantageous to deemed universities and top private colleges. Students, with a cut-off (minimum eligibility score) of 180 and above are uncertain of getting admissions in sought-after colleges through counselling. They are confused whether to join private institutions or wait for the counselling to begin,” said education consultant Jayaprakash Gandhi. Corroborating this, deemed universities, in their official press releases, claim to have witnessed a spike in applicants and cut-off scores based on which admission is carried out alongside entrance tests. This could be an indicator that toppers who could have secured admission through counselling may have joined deemed universities due to the delay. As far as top private engineering colleges affiliated to Anna University are concerned, there has been an increase in demand for integrated courses like MSc Data Sciences, business analytics and artificial intelligence, Gandhi added. Deadline to pay fees for these courses (under management quota) is nearing and some have opted for these courses, reducing the chance of more toppers joining Anna University colleges further, say experts. The counselling was already set to begin with 40,000 vacant seats as only 1.3 lakh applied for 1.7 lakh seats available. A senior official from Anna University said not conducting counselling as announced will make people lose trust and turn them towards institutions which have better infrastructure and placement record than affiliated colleges. “After vice-chancellor M K Surappa withdrew, the committee hasn’t utilised Anna University’s resources and they are feeling the heat now. The inexperience is reflecting in the form of delays,” the official added. When asked about the delay, the committee attributed it to it giving another chance for applicants who didn’t get their certificates verified properly and said it will not affect the admission process. Parents have requested for engineering counselling to begin on second or third day of medical counselling as cut-off scores of state board students are not high and the impact on medical admission is now mellowed down by NEET. AMMK Candidate List 2019.description: CHENNAI: AMMK deputy general secretary TTV Dhinakaran on Friday released the second and final list of candidates - 14 for the Lok Sabha polls and 9 for assembly bypoll in Tamil Nadu. The party has decided to field two of its heavyweight disqualified MLAs to contest Lok Sabha polls and to take on strong candidates from AIADMK alliance. Disqualified MLA from Andipatti and AMMK propaganda secretary, Thanga Tamilselvan, has been fielded from Theni Lok Sabha constituency, he will take on P Ravindranath Kumar, son of deputy chief minister and AIADMK coordinator O Paneerselvam. Disqualified MLA from Paapireddipatti and former minister P Palaniappan will be contesting the Lok Sabha polls from Dharmapuri constituency. He will take on PMK youth wing leader and former Union health minister Anbumani Ramadoss, who is contesting on behalf of the AIADMK-BJP-PMK alliance.| Full coverage of Lok Sabha elections in Tamil NaduBesides these two, AMMK has also selected another disqualified MLA, NG Parthibhan from Sholingar assembly segment, to contest Arakonam Lok Sabha constituency. He will take on former Unions minister of state S Jagathrakshakan of the DMK - Congress alliance on the seat. AMMK had earlier released its first list of 24 candidates for Lok Sabha and 9 candidates for assembly bypoll in the state last Sunday. By 2050, winters in Chennai will be warm.description: CHENNAI: “Chennai has no winters” is an oft-made remark about the city. But in future this could be true. Researchers at Anna University have found that due to climate change, there would be a 2°C rise in effective temperature during winter and post monsoon by 2050, making winters uncomfortable. Effective temperature is the combined effect of temperature and relative humidity on the human body and this determines thermal comfort – a major issue in cities across the world and expected to change in future due to climate change. Thermal comfort is calculated using the temperature humidity index or thermo-hygrometric index (THI). “For instance, if the temperature is 35°C in Chennai, the relative humidity makes us feel as if it is above 40°C,” said K Palanivelu, director, Centre for Climate Change and Adaptation Research, Anna University. Researchers studied this change in THI. Palanivelu and his co-researchers Anushiya Jeganathan and A Ramachandran observed changes in the past 60 years (1951-2010) of daily maximum temperature and relative humidity data of Chennai procured from Indian Meteorological Department to arrive at a projected THI in future. The study was made using a method to project future climate scenarios developed at the centre with the help of UK met office’s PRECIS (Providing Regional Climate for Impact Studies) software. “Long term analysis shows there is a steady increase of discomfort in the city,” said Anushiya Jeganathan, a member of the research team. The researchers said an increase in winter temperatures was noticed in many parts of the world, including Chennai. The changes in comfort level was studied in two phases — 1951-1980 and 1981-2010. The change in discomfort level saw a regular increase in the second phase when compared to the first, according to the research. During 1981-2010, the THI went up in all month except in June, August and September. “A significant increase is noticed in February (1.1°C) followed by January and March (1°C) for the period of 1981-2010,” the research said. This has been consistent with the projected data with mid-century (2041-2070) and end century (2071-2099) estimates showing an average rise of 2°C and 4.6°C. “The increase of discomfort level in winter months is distressing,” the research said. Researchers said the current trend puts the onus on urban planners who have to evolve climate-smart strategies. A very obvious measure is increasing green cover, said Palanivelu citing the example of a dip in temperature in and around the IIT-M and Raj Bhavan campus due to the extensive green cover. The researchers said studies across the world have shown an association between high temperatures and heat-related mortality. Combined with increased humidity, high temperatures could create more uncomfortable conditions and become lethal. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Doctors strike: Docs in most private hos.description: CHENNAI: Doctors in almost all private hospitals in Tamil Nadu cancelled “non-essential” appointments to patients starting 6am on Monday as part of a national protest called by the Indian Medical Association to condemn the assault on intern doctors in Kolkata. Patients, including those visiting from other states, were asked to return on Tuesday if they didn’t have pain or “emergency” needs. Doctors in several hospitals in Chennai, including Apollo Hospitals, SIMS Hospitals, Gleneagles Global and Fortis Malar, trimmed down their appointments and sent text messages and emails to patients with support from hospital managements. Inpatient services, operation theatres (including elective surgeries), lab services and emergency rooms were functioning. Posters announcing reasons for strike and doctors’ demands were displayed in several hospitals. “We are deeply pained to be forced to indulge in such attacks,” said posters announcing strikes. However, doctors at all government hospitals worked. "We expressed solidarity with the striking doctors by wearing black badges," said Tamil Nadu Government Doctors Association president Dr K Senthil. In private hospitals, some physicians took the day off while surgeons postponed consultation including post-operative appointments. As a result, emergency and trauma wards were overcrowded through the day. “I have fever and cough since last night. I need only a consultation, but I had to go to the emergency because I got no appointments. It wasn’t possible to wait for a day,” said 60-year-old Ramesh Kumar S, who retired from government service recently. In another hospital, doctors cancelled appointment given to a seven-year-old child and rescheduled it for Wednesday. "I took permission from my daughter's school for vaccination today. The revised schedule for me is such as burden because I have to reschedule my work appointments, talk to my daughter's school and coordinate with the autoriskshaw driver," said Madhumathi M, who works for a private bank. The strike would continue till 6am on Tuesday in an attempt to draw the government’s attention to doctors’ demands, said IMA state wing president Dr S Kanagasabapathy. “We have never seen such a big response to strike before,” he said. “There is a lot of anger among doctors because they often come under attack here too. Although Tamil Nadu was one of the first few states to bring legislations that protect doctors and hospitals, conviction rates have been very poor,” he said. Since the Tamil Nadu Medicare Service Persons and Medicare Service Institutions (Prevention of Violence and Damage or Loss to Property) Act, 2008 came into force, the state has registered about 33 cases and 13 people have been convicted. “Several times, complaints are not even registered. At least 19 states across the country have similar law, but we are now asking for a central Act that will be more stringent,” said IMA former national vice-president Dr TN Ravishankar. Doctors want punishment enhanced to up to 10 years of imprisonment with a fine that is nearly three times the cost of damage to the hospital. “We need not be paid all the money. Let the additional money go to government coffers, but it will instil some fear,” said Dr Kanagasabapathy. Doctors also want senior policemen, not below the rank of deputy superintendent or assistant commissioner of police, to investigate such attacks. Chanchal Lahiri.description: KOLKATA: After a day-long search for magician Chanchal Lahiri (41),   who disappeared   while performing an underwater escape act in the Hooghly, police on Monday fished out his body from near Howrah. Later in the evening, Lahiri's brother identified his body. An initial police probe established that Lahiri on Sunday had made several mistakes while attempting the stunt popularised by the famous illusionist and stunt performer Harry Houdini almost 100 years ago. Mandrake trying similar stunt earlierMMiC still in shock after magician’s deathLahiri, who was to come out of the water after being thrown in with his hands and feet bound, , but also wore cumbersome clothing and guards that made swimming in the strong current extremely difficult. Magician PC Sarkar, a master of such stunts, said perhaps Lahiri "needed a little more practice". Lahiri's team, too, waited about 15 minutes after he was lowered into the water to raise an alarm. Chanchal Lahiri on the boat moments before he started the stunt on Sunday Lahiri’s hands and legs were tied with ropes and he was chained with six locks. "When he did not surface for a long time, people panicked. Some onlookers said they saw a man struggling, seeking help, in the middle of the river. Police were informed and a team of divers from the disaster management group joined the rescue operation," said DC (Port) Syed Waquar Raza. Cops will probe if he took advantage of some lacunae on part of the administration and probably paid for it with his life. "A case of negligence is likely to be registered," said a source. Lahiri being lowered into the Hooghly river as he performed one of his tricks in KolkataMagician’s body found; peers say he didn’t take proper precaution Sources said Mandrake never mentioned in his permission letter that he was going to jump into the water. "Lahiri stated the stunt was to happen on a boat or vessel. Hence, we allowed him permission," Raza said. The letter added that he wanted to take photographs and perform an extra event around 1.30pm. The final dip made by Chanchal Lahiri"He performed almost an hour earlier. Hence, river traffic police was absent," said a Port division officer. Police said Lahiri drowned around 12.30pm and it is unclear whether he was performing or practising the act. Moments before the stunt on Sunday, Lahiri said, "If you perform a dangerous trick perfectly, you are a magician. If you fail, it is always tragic." Mandrake's body was fished out on Monday"Bound and chained, Mandrake was lowered 30 feet under water. Thousands watched and it is impossible the cops missed the entire episode when even politicians were present," claimed a friend on Monday. In 2013, when Lahiri performed the same stunt, he was assaulted by the crowd of onlookers, who claimed they felt cheated because they had seen through the trick. BJP List 2019 WB.description: KOLKATA: The BJP in its first list of 28 candidates for West Bengal has pinned hopes on its veterans and defectors from the ruling Trinamool Congress to take on the Mamata Banerjee's government in the state. Of the 28 candidates, nearly 25 are new faces, with a thrust on active political workers rather than greenhorns from the glamour world. The saffron party, which bagged two Lok Sabha seats in the 2014 elections, is now targeting 23 of the state's 42 constituencies. BJP Lok Sabha first full listUnlike the TMC list, which had 18 new faces and a mix of both old-timers and greenhorns, hardcore politicians and personalities from the film industry, the BJP has put faith on its own leaders and defectors from other parties. There are four women candidates and one Muslim nominee in the first list. Of the candidates, five had recently defected to the saffron party from the Trinamool Congress and one from the CPI(M). West Bengal: Track here Lok Sabha elections' full coverageUnion minister and BJP MP from Asansol Lok Sabha constituency Babul Supriyo has been renominated from the same seat and is pitted against actor Moon Moon Sen of the TMC. State BJP president Dilip Ghosh will contest from Medinipur seat against TMC leader Manas Bhunia. BJP national secretary Rahul Sinha will take on TMC heavyweight Sudip Bandopadhyay in Kolkata North Lok Sabha seat. State BJP vice-president and Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose grandnephew, Chandra Kumar Bose will contest from Kolkata South Lok Sabha seat. Former IPS officer Bharati Ghosh, once known to be close to Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee, will be fighting against TMC candidate and actor Dipak Adhikary, popularly known as 'Dev', from Ghatal Lok Sabha constituency. The BJP has fielded former Trinamool Congress MLA Arjun Singh from Barrackpur Lok Sabha seat. Singh, who had recently joined the saffron party, has been pitted against TMCs Dinesh Trivedi. In Coochbebar Lok Sabha seat, the party has fielded former TMC youth leader Nishith Pramanik, while in Jadavpur Lok Sabha seat, expelled TMC MP Anupam Hazra will contest against TMC's Mimi Chakraborty, an actor by profession. Another former TMC MP Soumitra Khan, who joined the BJP in January, has been given ticket from Bishnupur(SC) Lok Sabha seat. Former CPI(M) MLA Khagen Murmu, who too had switched over to the BJP, will contest from Malda North seat and will take on TMCs Mausam Benazir Noor, who had recently defected to the party from the Congress, in Malda Uttar seat. The Lok Sabha elections in the state will be held from April 11 till May 19 in seven phases. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Woman dies in stampede at PDS shop in Ta.description: TIRUVANNAMALAI: A 63-year-old woman died in a stampede at a PDS (public distribution system) shop at Inamkariyandhal in Tiruvannamalai district of Tamil Nadu on Monday. The woman, identified as Dhanabakiyam, was waiting to buy her monthly provisions. According to police, the stampede happened when the ration card holders – mostly women – moved forward. Later, Dhanabakiyam, who was caught in the stampede, was found lying unconscious on the floor. She was rushed to Government Tiruvannamalai Medical College and Hospital where she was declared brought dead. The Tiruvannamalai taluk police registered a case. Vijayalakshmi, a villager, said though the PDS outlet at Inamkariyandhal catered to more than 900 ration holders from three nearby villages, it was opened only twice a month. “Officials should take steps to open the outlet every day or they should open more PDS outlets in each village to avert such tragedies,” she said. However, taluk supply officer K Sumathi denied the allegation that the shop opened twice a month. Sumathi said there were around 200 ration card holders at the shop when the woman was found unconscious. “Preliminary inquiries revealed that the woman had skipped her breakfast. She fell unconscious while standing in a queue,” the officer said. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

TN: Poojas done, but temples struggle fo.description: CHENNAI: All temples are struggling for water despite special poojas and homams conducted to propitiate the rain god following instructions from the the Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments department. All large Shiva temples perform five abhishekams and six times pooja daily, using borewells drilled within a well or a tank and are now being aked to use water sparingly. “We completely depend on borewells within tanks as well as on temple premises. The six borewells at the Kaplaeeswarar temple in Mylapore are the only source. We are happy we have water in the borewells but over the last few days the pressure is low and we are keeping our fingers crossed,” said a senior HR&CE official. The situation is similar at other temples. “We have a little water in the tank but water for the use in the temple is only drawn from the borewell. We do the daily poojas and abishekams without any problem but we only hope there is rain in the coming days as the well inside the temple will have some water,” said an official at a temple in Saidapet. There were times when water tankers were used to fill temple tanks and it happened in Mylapore and Triplicane. But now even tankers are in huge demand and very few temples are using them. “At present, water is needed for abhishekams, in kitchens, for devotees and in rest rooms. For cooking and other uses, we purchase water, but for the purpose of abishekams, it is mostly borewell water,” said the HR&CE official. Last month, the department told temples to organise varuna poojas. “Temple officials must make oduvars (temple singers) recite Sundramurthi Nayanar’s 7th Thirumurai and Thevaram (sacred hyms in Tamil on Lord Shiva) seeking rain. Temple artists must be asked to either sing or play on the nathasvaram or violin Carnatic music ragas like Amirtravarshini, Megavarshini, Kedharam, Ananda Bhairavi, Rupa Kalyani and others,” said a cicular from the department. Sterner tests await AIADMK following tem.description: CHENNAI: The AIADMK leadership may have bought a temporary truce for its internal troubles by avoiding a detailed discussion on several issues plaguing the party at its June 12 meeting. Bigger tests, however, await it in selection of candidates for Rajya Sabha polls, the schedule for which could be announced in the next few days. With AIADMK coordinator and deputy chief minister O Panneerselvam having promised at the June 12 meeting, to announce the names of the 11-member steering committee in two weeks’ time, that too is yet to draw any attention so far. In the five days since that meeting, both OPS and joint coordinator and chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami were hardly in Chennai, with OPS away in his home town and EPS having had to attend meetings in New Delhi. “There has been no further discussion, within the party, on any issue after the June 12 meeting, barring a closed door meeting that OPS and EPS had along with party deputy coordinators K P Munusamy and R Vaithilingam soon after that meeting in the AIADMK headquarters. Now that EPS is back in Chennai from New Delhi and OPS expected to return to the city on Monday, things could kickstart,” a senior AIADMK leader, who did not want to be named, told TOI. On Saturday, Election Commission (EC) had announced the schedule for filling six Rajya Sabha seats, which fell vacant, in the states of Bihar, Gujarat and Odisha, with a formal notification to be issued on Tuesday. Soon, the announcement of schedule for filling the six Rajya Sabha seats from Tamil Nadu is expected to be made over next few days. “Despite the differences that continue to exist between them, the two leaders cannot delay deliberations any further. With just a few days for the schedule to be announced and several aspirants from within the party, especially with all the bigwigs now eyeing a seat in the Rajya Sabha, things cannot wait for long,” the leader said. Meanwhile, the promise made by OPS on steering committee could turn out to be a test for his leadership qualities. “This is not the first time OPS had made tall announcements at such party meetings. In the past too, he had insisted that the steering committee be constituted and that the party go back to the one-leader-onepost concept,” said another AIADMK leader. “But, he never followed them up in the subsequent meetings. If the same happens this time too, partymen will understand he uses such announcements as a diversionary tactic to escape scrutiny, especially in the wake of his recent failed attempt to get a berth for his son in the Union Cabinet,” said the leader. Rly parcel office clerks worked same shi.description: Chennai: In the ongoing inquiry at the parcel office of Chennai Central station, officials on Friday discovered something very curious: the same employee worked morning shift for the past several months on the parcel loading duty, while another worked the evening shifts. This is against vigilance and railway guidelines as rotation of shift is a must, especially for employees working in a sensitive area like the parcel office. This pattern was noticed in employees who handled cash at the parcel office as well. TOI has seen a copy of the attendance log for three months. Senior officials told TOI that the roster has been changed since. Informed sources said this was a key point in the modus operandi of the mafia that controls the parcel office. They decide which cargo gets loaded when, bypasses systems to aid under-weighment and takes bribe. TOI had reported how the mafia earns Rs 3 lakh every day in bribes from those who want to load their cargo on to trains. “The most lucrative time for working as loading clerk is in the morning, when inward parcels from trains from New Delhi and northern states arrive at Chennai. Similarly, the evening shift is lucrative as many perishable and non-perishable goods are loaded on to trains to Hyderabad, Kerala, Kolkata and Howrah,” said a source at the parcel office. Parcel supervisors who are in charge of ensuring rotation of clerks remain spectators, as influential union office-bearers are involved in this, said an official. For instance, the attendance sheets accessed by TOI show overwriting at many spots, where M (morning) is converted into L (leave) or R (rest) is converted into E (evening). In fact many of the employees have written to us that they want to be transferred out of the parcel office as they are unable to work alongside the mafia, said two sources, one an office-bearer of an employees union and another, an official in Chennai division of Southern Railway. Meanwhile, divisional railway manager P Mahesh sent out an internal note on Thursday, stating that every railway employee should carry an identity card on railway premises. “This came after it was found that unauthorised agents freely roamed the parcel office, claiming to be associated with the railways,” said an official involved in the investigation. Arvind Kejriwal.description: VISAKHAPATNAM: Delhi chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on Monday said that Congress President Rahul Gandhi has refused to forge an alliance with the AAP for the Lok Sabha polls in the national capital. Full coverage: Lok Sabha electionsTalking to reporters at the airport here, the AAP leader said he had met Gandhi recently and the Congress leader had refused to “join hands with the AAP”. Asked about Congress' Delhi unit president Sheila Dikshit's remarks that Kejriwal never approached her for an alliance, the chief minister said, “We have met Rahul Gandhi. Dikshit is not that important leader.” Kejriwal has been urging the Congress to stitch an alliance in Delhi for the Lok Sabha polls to keep the BJP away from power. Leaders in the Delhi unit of the Congress were divided over the issue of alliance with Dikshit and her three working presidents opposing it, party sources had said. A top source in the party had recently said that chances of alliance were "slim" considering its long term repercussions in Delhi. "The biggest question is how will Congress face the AAP in Assembly elections due in 2020 after the tie up. Also, the party does not gain much politically as it is being offered only 2-3 seats by Kejriwal," the source had said. Congress had drawn a blank in the 2014 parliamentary elections in Delhi. The talk of alliance was fuelled by the fact that the Congress and AAP had jointly polled more votes than the BJP that had walked away with all the seven seats in the national capital. Delhi has 7 Lok Sabha seats and it will go to polls on May 12. Chennai Metro Rail to conduct yoga camps.description: CHENNAI: Commuters walking into metro stations could learn a yoga pose or two before they board a train, as Chennai Metro Rail Limited (CMRL) is organising yoga camps at eight metro stations from June 20 to 23. The camp organised in association with Suthaveli Sabhai, a Pollachi-based Yoga institution, will be held as part of the International Yoga Day. The camp will be held in two sessions -- morning sessions at 6.30am at Central, Tirumangalam, Mannadi and Vadapalani stations and the evening sessions will be at 5.30pm at Saidapet, Egmore, St Thomas Mount and Ashok Nagar. A CMRL official said members of the public also can walk in to the metro stations and participate in the camp. “They can bring their families too,” an official said. Anyone aged from eight to 80 years can attend the yoga camp. A N Dhanasekaran, who has 40 years experience in teaching yoga, will be conducting these camps. Satta King 2019.description: NEW DELHI: Satta Matka is a form of gambling or lottery that had originated before the Independence of India.Originally, the game of Matka gambling involved betting on the opening and closing rates of cotton as transmitted to the Bombay Cotton Exchange from the New York Cotton Exchange, via teleprinters.The modern-day Matka gambling/ Satta King is based on random number selection and betting. The players participating in the Satta Matka game/ gambling are required to choose the right number for winning the game. The player who wins the game becomes Satta King and is rewarded financially. Two of the most famous Matka games are - Kalyan and Worli. The Kalyan Matka gambling was started by Kalyanji Bhagat, a farmer from Gujarat, in 1962 and it ran for all days of the week. Another Matka gambling, New Worli Matka, was started by the Rattan Khatri in 1964 with slight modifications to the rules of the game. Khatri’s Matka ran only five days a week, from Monday to Friday.The modern Matka business is centred around Maharashtra.Some of the terms used in the game and their meaning is given below:    Term Meaning   Matka Matka means earthen pot that were used to draw numbers   Single Any digit between 0 and 9   Jodi/Pair Any pair of two digits between 00 and 99    Patti/Panna Three digit number    Open result / close result Outcome of matka betting   Berij Berij is last digit of jodi's/pair's sum The Google 2018 trends data shows that 'satta' and 'matka' were the top searched words in the Madhya Pradesh state in the year 2018. As per the Google data, 'satta' was the 4th most searched word with a score of 36 and 'matka' came 6th with a score of 23.Any form of Satta Matka gambling is illegal in India.Disclaimer: This content is for reference purpose only and The Times of India claims no ownership of this content. The Times of India does not support or promote piracy in any manner.Download The Times of India News App for Latest India News.

Priyanka Gandhi.description: RAE BARELI: In her scathing attack on BJP and Modi government, Congress general secretary Priyanka Gandhi said that Congress doesn't need any certificate from anyone to prove its nationalist feelings. "Ye brashtachar ki baat karnewale sabse bade brashta hain… kaam ki baat karte hain magar sabse bade nikamme hain… dharma ki baat karne wale sabse bada adharm kar rahe hain - dharm ka istemal kar rahe hain… saheedon ka istemal kar rahe hain - sirf rajinit ke liye (They are talking of acting against corruption but are corrupt themselves… they talk of work but are good for nothing… they talk of dharma (read duties) but indulge in adharma by defying its norms - they use religion and martyrs for political interests)," Priyanka stated in her closed door meeting with cadres on Thursday. The Congress leader hit out at BJP's strategy of playing the nationalist card. "We are Congress… we launched the freedom movement… gave our blood and sweat… braved British atrocities … we don't need any certificate to prove our nationalist feelings especially from the ones who apologised to the British at that time", asserted Priyanka, urging the workers to go to every household in their area and meet every voter. She directed the workers to apprise the voters that the 2019 Lok Sabha election was as important as the freedom movement. Infusing energy in them she said, "Don't be afraid of anything as this is a weak government. Only a weak government curbs the voice of the people, which is a crime in democracy." Priyanka asked the workers to stand up for their leader whose only dream is the progress of India and its people. "Rahul thinks of the people without any vested interest," Priyanka said citing the example of her conversation with Rahul on the issue of using self-help group women for campaigning. "When I proposed to him this idea, he simply denied… saying that I created the SHGs to empower women, not use them in any way," Priyanka said quoting her brother. The Congress general secretary told the workers that she was working on mission 2022. "We will, with your support, form the government in 2022. And once we come, we will stay here for long on the basis of our hard work," she said adding that the hard-workers would be adequately rewarded. Pawan Kalyan.description: GUNTUR: Stating that they will bulldoze bastions of TDP and YSR Congress, Janasena president Pawan Kalyan promised to grant Rs 5,000 pension to all farmers in the state. He said they will also grant Rs 8,000 crop incentive to farmers soon after coming into power in the next elections. Pawan further said his government would provide six to 10 LPG cylinders free-of-cost to each family every year. and also promised to fill 3 lakh vacancies in the government departments to provide jobs to youth. Addressing a meeting in Guntur on Monday, Pawan said that the future of the state did not mean the future of Lokesh and Jagan but it was the future of the people. “The space on the state’s political stage is not TDP’s and YSRC’s property as youth and women are eager to bring change through Jana Sena.” “TDP had lost moral right to rule the state as chief minister N Chandrababu Naidu had no control over his legislators who indulged in illegal activities,” Pawan said adding that he jumped into the political arena to bring in a change in the lives of commoners. “We supported TDP and BJP in the last elections with a hope to transform the state. Unfortunately, both of them have shattered our dreams,” he said. “Guntur city has been left in a lurch despite located a few kilometres away from the capital city. The entire city has been dug out in the guise of laying underground drainage scheme and left without repair. How shocking it is to see 30 people dying of diarrhoea in a city like Guntur? Is it not the failure of the state government? Opposition leader Jaganmohan Reddy is equally responsible for the tragedy as he never dared to question the government by going to the assembly,” he said. He further said they would construct apartments exclusively for Muslims in the city. He appealed to people to support his candidates Chandrasekhar (Guntur West), Zia-Ur-Rehman (East) and MP candidate Bonaboina Srinivas Yadav in the elections, Pawan said they fielded a BC candidate Srinivasa Yadav whereas TDP and YSRC both have given tickets to their own communities. Those who gain weight, lose teeth: Chenn.description: CHENNAI: There are plenty of reasons to lose weight. Here is another: a new city-based study has found that overweight people lost more teeth than their normal-weight peers. Although surprising, the link isn’t a newly discovered one, and doctors across the world are increasing connecting body mass index to dental health. Dentists researched about 500 people -- both men and women -- aged 40 years and older with missing posterior teeth (not rehabilitated with any prosthesis) through clinical history and intraoral examination for the study called, ‘Body Mass Index and Tooth Loss: An Epidemiological Study in a Sample of Suburban South Indian Population’. Among the 260 women in the study group, 133 were obese and 35 were overweight. Of the 240 men in the group, 73 were obese and 74 were overweight. The biggest number of high tooth loss in both genders was among those who are obese. At least 55 women in the obese group suffered high tooth loss compared to 27 men in the same group. “There is no known mechanism that explains the exact relationship between obesity, tooth loss, and gender differences. It has been speculated that these changes are mediated by eating behaviour of the individual,” said the corresponding author Dr Parthasarathy Natarajan, department of prosthodontics, at Faculty of Dental Sciences, Sri Ramachandra Institute of Higher Education and Research. The results, published in the Journal of Pharmacy and Bioallied Sciences allowed the authors to conclude that BMI and tooth loss are interrelated. Further analysis showed 70% of obese women were from the low socioeconomic group, which is significantly higher than any other group. The authors say the study has a limitation as the medical diseases are only self-reported and they have not done an assessment of physical activity, food preferences of the individuals, and level of education was performed. “A case-control study with more samples may give us better conclusive evidence,” they said. But studies done abroad that took account factors such as blood sugar levels, smoking, and eating and exercise habits, with age and gender also showed a significant link between obesity and dental health. Doctors say obesity contributes to inflammation in the body, which has long been associated with gum disease. “Diseases of the mouth have long been associated with cardiac diseases and some cancers. The mouth is generally a gateway to good health, a reason why most general physicians look into your mouth during the examination,” said diabetologist Dr V Mohan. Anantnag Encounter.description: SRINAGAR: An Army Major died while another officer of the same rank and two soldiers were injured in a gunfight at Bidoora village, in Achabal area of south Kashmir's Anantnag district, on Monday, a defence spokesman said. A Pakistani terrorist was killed in the encounter. Major Ketan Sharma of 19 Rashtriya Rifles, who died in the Achabal encounter, belonged to Meerut. A police officer said they had found the body of a Pakistani terrorist and seized arms and ammunition from the encounter site. The identity of the slain terrorist was being ascertained. In another attack, at least nine Army soldiers were injured in an IED blast that targeted a security vehicle of 44 RR at Aarihal village in Pulwama on Monday evening. Those injured in the Achabal gunfight and IED blast were rushed to the Army's 92 Base hospital in Srinagar, officials said. In the third attack in 24 hours, terrorists lobbed a grenade at the headquarters of the 180 CRPF battalion camp in Tral sub-district of Pulwama late on Monday evening. The grenade exploded outside the headquarters. No casualties have been reported. The first attack happened on Monday morning when a team of security men was on a cordon-and-search operation in Achabal. Terrorists fired at the team, who then retaliated. In the Pulwama attack, the terrorists after setting off the IED, opened fire at the Army vehicle. "Initial reports reveal the vehicle suffered extensive damage," the official said. Three of the soldiers injured in the blast were said to be serious, sources said. Soon after the attack, Army, police and SOG reinforcements were rushed to the spot and a massive search operation was launched. A defence spokesman, however, said some of the men sustained minor injuries in the IED blast. Damage was minimal due to the alertness of the patrol party, he said. The vehicle was an armoured ALS and not a Casspir (a mine-resistant, ambush-protected vehicle), he added. BJP List 2019 Tamilnadu.description: CHENNAI: The BJP's Tamil Nadu candidates list announced on Thursday was on expected lines, with Union minister Pon Radhakrishnan being fielded from Kanyakumari, state chief Tamilisai Soundararajan in Tuticorin, national secretary H Raja in Sivaganga, C P Radhakrishnan in Coimbatore and vice-president Nainar Nagendran in Ramanathapuram. While Pon Radhakrishnan and Raja will fight Congress, which is yet to name candidates for its nine seats in DMK alliance, Tamilisai will cross swords with DMK heavyweight Kanimozhi in Tuticorin. H Raja to contest from Sivaganga for third timeH Raja is contesting from Sivaganga for the third time. In 2014, he came third with 1.33 lakh votes, while in 1999, he came second. It will be a keenly fought battle between Tamilisai and DMK’s state women wing secretary and Rajya Sabha MP K Kanimozhi in Tuticorin. Though Tamilisai initially preferred to contest from Chennai South, which has a sizeable votebank for the party, she finally settled for Tuticorin. AIADMK was keen on retaining south Chennai for sitting MP, J Jayavardhan, son of fisheries minister D Jayakumar. Former TN BJP chief Radhakrishnan will face CPM’s P R Natarajan in Coimbatore. This is the fifth time that Radhakrishnan has been fielded in Coimbatore, a BJP stronghold. While he won two consecutive Lok Sabha elections in 1998 and 1999, he was defeated in the 2004 and 2014 polls. Nainar Nagendran has been pitted against DMK’s IUML candidate K Nawaz Kani. While the party made a quick decision on candidates for four constituencies, Ramanathapuram delayed matters considering the keen contest for the seat among some senior leaders.
